content: Singaporean politician **Ong Pang Boon** [DUNU](/wiki/Darjah_Utama_Nila_Utama) ([Chinese](/wiki/Chinese_language): 王邦文; [Pe̍h-ōe-jī](/wiki/Pe%CC%8Dh-%C5%8De-j%C4%AB): *Ông Pang-bûn*; [pinyin](/wiki/Pinyin): *Wáng Bāngwén*; born 28 March 1929) is a Singaporean retired politician who served as [Minister for Home Affairs](/wiki/Ministry_of_Home_Affairs_(Singapore)#Ministers) between 1959 and 1963 and again for a short period of time in 1970, [Minister for Education](/wiki/Ministry_of_Education_(Singapore)#Ministers) between 1963 and 1970, [Minister for Labour](/wiki/Ministry_of_Manpower_(Singapore)#Ministers) between 1971 and 1981, and [Minister for the Environment](/wiki/Ministry_of_the_Environment_and_Water_Resources_(Singapore)#Ministers) between 1981 and 1985. ## Early life and education Born in [Kuala Lumpur](/wiki/Kuala_Lumpur) during [British colonial rule](/wiki/Federated_Malay_States), Ong attended the [Methodist Boys' School](/wiki/Methodist_Boys%27_School_(Kuala_Lumpur)) in Kuala Lumpur before enrolling into the [University of Malaya](/wiki/University_of_Malaya) at Singapore campus (now the [National University of Singapore](/wiki/National_University_of_Singapore)), where he studied [geography](/wiki/Geography). Ong's wife [Chan Choy Siong](/wiki/Chan_Choy_Siong), a politician and [women's rights](/wiki/Women%27s_rights) activist, died in a car accident in 1981, leaving behind her husband and their three children. ## Political career In 1955, Ong's foray into politics began as a polling agent for [Lee Kuan Yew](/wiki/Lee_Kuan_Yew) in the [1955 legislative assembly election](/wiki/1955_Singaporean_general_election). In 1956, Lee Kuan Yew wrote to Ong and offered him a job as party organising secretary for the PAP. He stood for election in the 21 December 1957 for the fully elected [City Council of Singapore](/wiki/City_Council_of_Singapore) as a candidate for the [Tanjong Pagar](/wiki/Tanjong_Pagar) ward and was successfully returned and became the first and only ever Deputy Mayor. He held the post until he resigned in April 1959 to contest the [Legislative Assembly election](/wiki/1959_Singaporean_general_election) as the PAP's candidate for [Telok Ayer](/wiki/Telok_Ayer_Single_Member_Constituency). This was to be the first Legislative Assembly in which all seats were elected. He won the seat, which he retained till his retirement in 1988. He was subsequently appointed as [Minister for Home Affairs](/wiki/Minister_for_Home_Affairs_(Singapore)) in the first self-government [Cabinet](/wiki/Cabinet_(government)) and played a key role to eradicating yellow culture and crime in Singapore society. His cabinet appointment also made him part of the [Internal Security Council](/wiki/Internal_Security_Council) which sanctioned [Operation Coldstore](/wiki/Operation_Coldstore) in 1963. From 1963 to 1970, Ong took on the highly sensitive [Education ministerial portfolio](/wiki/Minister_for_Education_(Singapore)) at a time when [Chinese language](/wiki/Chinese_language) culture and education issues were highly politicised. By increasing the teaching of [English](/wiki/Singapore_English) in Chinese schools and vice versa, he was instrumental in laying the foundation for [Singapore's bilingual language policy](/wiki/Language_planning_and_policy_in_Singapore). In 1970, Ong became the [Labour Minister](/wiki/Minister_for_Labour_(Singapore)). In 1980, he took over as the Environment Minister. In 1984, he stepped down from the Cabinet to make way for younger leaders. However, he displayed some unhappiness at the pace and manner by which he was sidelined from the political scene. He retired from politics in 1988 when his constituency of Telok Ayer was eliminated in the [3 September 1988 general election](/wiki/1988_Singaporean_general_election). Lee recognised Ong's displeasure in a public letter of appreciation: "... I agree with you. You also had misgivings (about some newcomers), as had Chin Chye (referring to [Toh Chin Chye](/wiki/Toh_Chin_Chye)), over the speed of self-renewal and the effect it was having on the morale of the old guard MPs." Ong is considered as one of the "Old Guard", the first generation of leaders of independent Singapore. He is the sole remaining living member, after [Jek Yeun Thong](/wiki/Jek_Yeun_Thong)'s passing in June 2018. ## Philanthropic work Ong continued to serve the society through his involvement in the community. Ong, who previously served as the vice-chairman of [Singapore Hokkien Huay Kuan](/wiki/Singapore_Hokkien_Huay_Kuan) in the 2000s, is currently serving in the Board of Governors of the association. ## Awards and decorations - [Order of the Nila Utama (First Class)](/wiki/Darjah_Utama_Nila_Utama), in 1990. ## Bibliography - Lam, Peng Er and Tan, Kevin (Ed.) (2000). *Lee's lieutenants : Singapore's old guard*. Singapore: Allen & Unwin. [ISBN](/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)) 1-86508-172-8
title: Ong Pang Boon
